text: hi welcome back to my cupcake addiction
today I'm showing you something super
cool we're going to be making skittles
sanding sugar so we're talking sprinkles
that taste like skittles but look like
sprinkles let's get started to make your
skin will standing sugar you're going to
need a really high-powered food
processor or a blender I'm using a food
processor but you could also use
something like the Thermomix or a
Vitamix if you have one I've got all of
my skittles that Ollie and I
painstakingly separated I've got this
little sharp kind of a scraper you can
use a sharp knife here but something
with a nice blade a spatula and assorted
food colors in the same colors as my
skittles off to the side I've got a
baking tray lined with some baking paper
and I've also got a sieve or a sifter
I've already made batches in yellow
orange and green so we're going to be
working through some of the other colors
of the rainbow today to begin with you
want to take your skittles and just pop
them into your food processor or your
blender and then we're gonna start that
out bear in mind this is going to be
super noisy it's like blending rocks the
time it takes to pulverize these is
going to vary anywhere from about 20
seconds all the way up to about 5
minutes it just depends on the strength
of your machine and the quality of your
blades you can leave the colors as is
but for me they're a bit pale so I'm
taking some of my pink gel food coloring
try not to put too much liquid in here
because you're going to need to dry it
out after you color it even if you don't
add any food coloring you still need to
dry this out because the skittles have
got that sticky Center you kind of need
to bake them off for a little while so
that they turn into really nice dry
sanding sugar you can start your food
presents up again and it should only
take you about 10 or 20 seconds just to
mix that color through once it's mixed
you want to take your pre-prepared
baking tray and just using a spatula
scrape out all of your skittles mix you
can see here how sticky it is so this is
why we really need to dry it out now
before you start drying it out you don't
want to leave it in this little mound
you kind of want to spread it out so
that's where my scraper comes in I
really am just using the sharp blade of
this to kind of separate the skittles
and really even them out on the tray
once they're nice and even pop them off
into a really really low oven so
is at its lowest possible fan-forced
setting which is 50 degrees Celsius
that's going to take a couple of hours
at that really low temperature and when
it comes out of the oven you can see
we've switched to blue because that's
been drying out for the last couple of
hours you should have a really nice dry
crumbly mix it will have clumped
together a little bit while it's in the
oven
as it kind of melts and as that sticky
stuff from inside the skittles starts to
kind of cook off a bit past your sanding
sugar through the sifter and that's kind
of going to grate down those little bits
but only your dry sanding sugar is going
to go through and you'll be left with
some little sticky clumps at the end
don't be tempted to put those in because
we need to have removed all of the
moisture from our sanding sugar you can
store your completed sugar airtight in a
ziploc bag for several weeks even up to
a few months make sure that you do dry
them out really really well because if
you leave any moisture in those skittles
your mix is going to clump together and
it's going to decrease that shelf-life
you can use this to decorate your cakes
cupcakes and cookies you can sprinkle it
over desserts and ice cream it's just
like sandy sugar but this one tastes
amazingly like skittles you are welcome
